titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Account Books Collection
titlestmt.author: compiled by William E. Brown, Jr.

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 08:18

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: An artificial collection of account books and financial volumes, ca. 1680-1930, relating to such occupations as: farmers, merchants, traders, millers, blacksmiths, lawyers, manufacturers, laborers, physicians, shoemakers, carpenters, tailors, and cigar makers. Materials relating to private organizations and businesses are also included. The collection focuses on the Connecticut and New England region.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Account Books Collection (MS 29). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in three series and one addition: I. Volumes. II. Oversized Volumes. III. Numerical.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Accounts Book Collection is an artificial collection of account books and financial volumes, 1680-1925, relating to such occupations as: farmers, merchants, traders, millers, blacksmiths, lawyers, manufacturers, laborers, physicians, shoemakers, carpenters, tailors, and cigar makers. Materials relating to private organizations and businesses are also included. The collection focuses upon Connecticut and the New England region. These volumes are a compilation of purchases and gifts for several years (ca. 1927-1958).
Volumes in SERIES I and II frequently relate to the same individual(s) and/or corporate body. Cross-references are provided to link appropriate volumes in each series.

SERIES I, VOLUMES, 1680-1911, and SERIES II, OVERSIZED VOLUMES, 1706-1903, contain business accounts and financial records in bound form, including account books, daybooks, ledgers, journals, and cashbooks. The daily financial transactions of individuals and businesses are recorded in these volumes. An individual or corporate body may be represented by a single volume or by several volumes from the type noted above.

Among the earliest volumes is one attributed to William Alley (1680) who commanded theExpectation, a ship of the East India Company. Many of the volumes record the financial transactions of Connecticut citizens in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. Accounts of farmers frequently record purchases of supplies and equipment while also documenting various other activities including the sale of produce, animals, crops, and other goods. Related transactions including the rental and lease of land, the hauling and transport of goods, and the fees for services such as masonry work, shoemaking, daily labor, weaving, carpentry, and other tasks are included

The financial transcations of merchants and shopkeepers detail the inventories of general stores, druggists, and store owners, in addition to recording the expenditure and receipt of cash transactions. The sale of a wide variety of goods, including meat, groceries, cloth, dry goods, shoes, hides, farm produce, wood, leather products, buttons, hats, and other items is recorded.

Several volumes which relate entirely or in part to shoemaking are located in the collection. Volumes for Leverett Allen, D.S. Barlow and Son, Elisha Bradley, Joseph and Reuben Bunnel, Simeon Chittenden, Asahel Clark, Abraham Cooper, Benjamin and Japhet Curtiss, Chandler Fay, William Fitch, Joel Morehouse, and Joseph Peck all contain records of shoemaking or shoe repair work performed as a business or as a supplement to farm work.
The volumes are frequently in poor condition with entries written in the daily course of business transactions, and thus not always legible.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown, though much of the material in this collection is likely in the public domain. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains volumes of business accounts and financial records arranged in alphabetical order by the name of the individual or corporate body. Unidentified volumes (boxes 94-100) are arranged in approximate chronological order and, whenever possible, identified by the geographic location and/or type of volume.

did.unittitle: Dibble, Philo F. and Marcus Platt
Hill and Company; Hill and Upson
Peck, Henry L. and Henry Smith; Peck and Somers
[U.S. Patent Button, Rivet, Needle Machine Manufacturing Company?]
Marble Dale, CT farmer and teamster
[New Haven, CT?] grain and oyster dealers
Clinton, CT grocery and dry goods
Meriden, CT farmer and hardware dealer

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains business accounts and financial records arranged in alphabetical order by the name of the individual and/or corporate body.
Unidentified volumes (boxes 149-152) are arranged in approximate chronological order and, whenever possible, identified by the geographic location and type of volume.

did.unittitle: Gillette, Henry S.; and Watson, Wellington, and Sons
Peck, Henry L., and Henry Smith Peck, and Peck and Somers
Smith, Isaac, John, and George H.
Clinton, CT grocery and dry goods

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains business accounts and financial records arranged in numerical order, by volume number. Each volume is assigned a number and, whenever possible, is identified by the individual and/or corporate owner, the geographic location, and the type of volume.

did.unittitle: No. 1: Longfellow Literary Association, N.Y.: treasurer's records
No. 2: Brubacher, John Seiler: journal of expenses during first year of marriage, Troy, N.Y.
No. 4: G & H Company, Boston: invoice and letterbook
No. 5: Unidentified [New Haven grocer?]: account book, scrapbook
No. 6: Blanchard, Amos: boarding accounts for students of Phillips Academy, Andover, Massachusetts
No. 7: Cooke, Increase & Company, New Haven [bookseller]: exchange book
No. 8: Southworth, Edward Wells: accounts of his estate
No. 9: [Crowell, T. N.]: ledger kept by a Connecticut hardware merchant, with accounts for boarders and employees
No. 10: Unidentified account book, in German, re: sale of cloth
No. 11: Newton, Edmund [Brookfield, Connecticut]: account book, poems, songs, miscellaneous writings
No. 12: Morse, William W. [New Haven printer]: daybook, scrapbook
No. 13: Watrous, George Stone: account book kept in kobe, Japan
No. 14: Wardwell, Claison Shaw [N.Y. dentist]: 2 account books
No. 15: Elwood, Everett S.: 2 household account books
No. 16: [New Haven militia company?]: tally book
No. 19: Williams, Frederick Wareham: account book kept while a student at Sheffield Scientific School, New Haven
No. 3: Half-Way House, Thousand Islands: 2 tavern account books
No. 21: Cooke, Increase & Company, New Haven [bookseller]: "Yale College journal"
Ledger of unidentified local tradesman/contractor [contains some items pertaining to Yale College]
